structured.description: A `CorsConfig` class that configures CORS settings for a Spring Web MVC application. The class uses Spring's `@Configuration` annotation and the `Bean` annotation to create a `WebMvcConfigurer` instance that adds CORS mappings to the registry. The CORS mappings allow incoming requests from specified origins, specify which HTTP methods are allowed, headers that can be accessed, and credentials that can be included in the response. The `allowedOrigins` field is annotated with `@Value` to retrieve a list of allowed origins from a properties file.

items.description: Is a configuration class that enables Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) for a Spring Web MVC application. It defines an array of allowed origins and allows all methods, headers, and credentials by default.
items.name: CorsConfig

items.description: Configures CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) settings for a web application by adding mapping, allowing origins, methods, headers, and credentials.

returns.description:
a configuration that allows cross-origin resource sharing for all methods, headers, and origins.

* `allowedOrigins`: The list of allowed origins for CORS requests.
* `allowedMethods`: The list of allowed HTTP methods for CORS requests.
* `allowedHeaders`: The list of allowed headers for CORS requests.
* `exposedHeaders`: The list of exposed headers for CORS requests.
* `allowCredentials`: Whether credentials (e.g., cookies, Authorization header) are allowed in CORS requests.

usage.description: This code would allow cross-origin requests on the server by setting the allowed origins and exposing headers.

items.name: corsConfigurer

items.description: Adds CORS mappings to a registry, allowing requests from any origin and specifying allowed methods, headers, and credentials.

params.name: registry
params.description: Cors registry that is being modified to add new mappings.

usage.description: This code sets the CORS policy for the entire application, allowing all origins and methods, as well as exposing specific headers such as token and userId. The allowCredentials parameter is set to true, which allows the server to accept cookies from any domain.
